general.how are you: I'm just a bot, but I'm doing great! How about you?
general.what is your name: I'm a medical chatbot here to help with health-related inquiries!
general.who created you: I was developed by a team of experts in healthcare and technology.

symptoms.fever: Fever can be a sign of infection. Please rest, stay hydrated, and monitor your temperature. If it persists, consult a doctor.
symptoms.headache: A headache can be caused by stress, dehydration, or other factors. Try resting and drinking water. If severe, seek medical advice.
symptoms.cough: A cough may be due to a cold, allergies, or infections. If persistent, consult a healthcare provider.
symptoms.cold: A common cold is caused by a virus. Stay warm, drink fluids, and rest. If symptoms last more than 10 days, see a doctor.
symptoms.sore throat: Sore throats can be caused by infections, allergies, or dry air. Try warm tea, honey, or throat lozenges.
symptoms.stomach pain: Stomach pain can be due to indigestion, gas, or infections. Drink water, rest, and avoid spicy foods.
symptoms.vomiting: Vomiting may be caused by food poisoning or infections. Stay hydrated and avoid solid food until you feel better.
symptoms.diarrhea: Diarrhea can be caused by infections or food intolerance. Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
symptoms.back pain: Back pain may be caused by poor posture, strain, or injury. Try stretching, resting, and applying heat or ice.
symptoms.dizziness: Dizziness can result from dehydration, low blood pressure, or vertigo. Sit down and drink water. If severe, seek medical help.

first_aid.burn: For minor burns, cool the area under running water for 10 minutes and apply aloe vera or a sterile bandage.
first_aid.cut: Clean the wound with water, apply antiseptic, and cover with a sterile bandage.
first_aid.choking: If someone is choking, encourage them to cough. If they can't breathe, perform the Heimlich maneuver.
first_aid.nosebleed: Pinch the nostrils together and lean forward slightly. Apply ice to the nose if bleeding continues.
first_aid.fracture: Keep the injured area still, support with a splint, and seek medical help immediately.
first_aid.sprain: Rest the injured area, apply ice, compress with a bandage, and keep it elevated.
first_aid.poisoning: If someone has ingested poison, call emergency services and do not induce vomiting unless advised.
first_aid.heat stroke: Move the person to a cool place, apply cold compresses, and provide fluids. Seek medical help if symptoms worsen.

medicine.paracetamol: Paracetamol is used to reduce fever and relieve pain. Follow dosage instructions and do not exceed the recommended limit.
medicine.ibuprofen: Ibuprofen is an anti-inflammatory drug used for pain relief. Take it with food to avoid stomach issues.
medicine.antacid: Antacids help relieve heartburn and acid reflux. Do not overuse them to avoid side effects.
medicine.antibiotics: Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections. Take them as prescribed and do not stop early.
medicine.antihistamine: Antihistamines help with allergies, itching, and cold symptoms. May cause drowsiness.
medicine.cough syrup: Cough syrups can help relieve dry or wet coughs. Follow the recommended dosage.
medicine.ORS: Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) helps prevent dehydration in diarrhea. Mix in water and drink as needed.
medicine.aspirin: Aspirin is a pain reliever and blood thinner. Do not use it if you have a bleeding disorder.

emergency.heart attack: Call emergency services immediately. Help the person sit down and loosen any tight clothing. If they are conscious, give them aspirin if available.
emergency.stroke: Recognize signs of stroke (FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency). Act quickly!
emergency.seizure: Do not restrain the person. Keep the area safe and time the seizure. If it lasts more than 5 minutes, call emergency services.
emergency.unconsciousness: Check for breathing and pulse. If absent, perform CPR and call emergency services.
emergency.allergic reaction: For mild allergies, take an antihistamine. For severe reactions (anaphylaxis), use an epinephrine injection (EpiPen) and seek emergency help.
emergency.asthma attack: Help the person use their inhaler. If symptoms persist, seek emergency medical attention.
emergency.electric shock: Turn off the power source if safe. Check for breathing and pulse, and call emergency services.

mental_health.stress: Practice deep breathing, meditation, and exercise. Talk to someone if you feel overwhelmed.
mental_health.anxiety: Try slow breathing techniques and relaxation exercises. Seek professional help if anxiety is persistent.
mental_health.depression: Talk to a trusted person or mental health professional. Stay active and engage in positive activities.
mental_health.panic attack: Breathe slowly and deeply, focus on a single object, and remind yourself that it will pass.
mental_health.insomnia: Try a bedtime routine, reduce screen time before sleep, and avoid caffeine in the evening.

nutrition.healthy diet: Eat a balanced diet with fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains.
nutrition.hydration: Drink at least 8 glasses of water a day to stay hydrated.
nutrition.weight loss: Maintain a calorie deficit, exercise regularly, and eat nutrient-rich foods.
nutrition.weight gain: Increase protein and calorie intake with healthy foods like nuts, avocados, and lean meats.
nutrition.vitamin deficiency: Eat a variety of foods to get enough vitamins. Consider supplements if needed.
